title: Tasmanian energy bonanza hinges on funding rework
text:
"One of the things we have been talking to regulators and government on in particular is coming up with a fair pricing model," said Lance Balcombe, chief executive of TasNetworks, suggesting the Marinus Link be recognised as national infrastructure and attract federal funding.

"It would be a pretty perverse outcome if Tasmanian customers were paying a large slice of the interconnector costs but weren't receiving much benefit for that.

"In order for this project to proceed that pricing matter has got to be dealt with; all stakeholders are aware and we are working towards a solution."

Still, a spokesman for federal Energy Minister Angus Taylor was cautious, given the feasibility work is still underway: "The government has provided $71 million to support feasibility and business case development for Marinus Link and Battery of the Nation," he said, while adding that a second interconnector with Tasmania and new dispatchable generation and storage would alleviate the significant supply and demand pressures seen in Victoria and South Australia last summer.

The comments come as the Grattan Institute launched an attack on federal and state government intervention into the energy market, including the federal government-owned Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project and the Underwriting New Generation Investments (UNGI) program, which would provide support for new on-demand generation plants.

Grattan, a respected think tank, said the moves and others including the "big stick" forced divestment legislation, were deterring private investment in needed new electricity supply, criticism that was strenuously rejected by Mr Taylor.

In the current environment...it is hard to make a business case by itself for investing in long-term storage. — Steve Davy, Hydro Tasmania CEO

Yet Steve Davy, chief executive of Hydro Tasmania, which is proposing the 'Battery of the Nation' pumped hydro part of the Tasmanian project, strongly backed the UNGI scheme and its aims.

Advertisement

"In the current environment ... it is hard to make a business case by itself for investing in long-term storage," Mr Davy told The Australian Financial Review.

"The three reasons the government are saying on why they are embarking on UNGI are correct," he added, pointing to the need to stimulate investment in flexible generation capacity, increasing generation to put downward pressure on prices and encouraging new entrants into the market to spur competition.

"That's what the federal government says they are doing with UNGI and I think those are good objectives to meet," he said.

Under the Battery of the Nation project, Hydro Tasmania is assessing its three leading pumped hydro opportunities identified among some 4800 megawatts in total, with a view to developing the first to supply the mainland through Marinus Link. The transmission cable, which could come online in 2027-28, would also unlock highly cost-effective wind power, fed by the famous Roaring Forties, currently lying untapped because of constraints in the existing Basslink interconnector.

Mr Balcombe said the Tasmanian project would work "in concert" with the 2000 MW Snowy 2.0 pumped hydro project currently under development.

"Our perspective is that there is room for both," he said, pointing to estimates that about 12,000 MW of coal-fired generation would retire by 2035, needing to be replaced by about 40,000 MW wind and solar, complemented by about 8000 MW of dispatchable generation.
description: A second interconnector between Tasmania and Victoria would open up a bank of clean green energy and storage for the National Electricity Market but funding hurdles need to be overcome.
